subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Update on intelligent Senior QS Font.
msgSnippet: You re right, most font editing tools either have not anough functions or cost a lot. Especialy since I would only be doing this as a hobby. And yes it would
messageBody:
You're right, most font editing tools either have not
anough functions or cost a lot. Especialy since I
would only be doing this as a hobby. And yes it would
require both adjusting the kerning and playing with
each chararter's shape. A lot of hand working.

Good luck with your effort!
Chuck


--- fctarbox3 <rtarbox@...> wrote:
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com,
>
> Just because it looks like fun to me, I'm probably
> going to code the
> Layout properties I think a QS font should have.
> The end result is
> a file that I can use to turn practically any
> existing TrueType QS
> font into an OpenType font that intelligently
> produces Senior QS.
>
> FYI. No expected delivery date; might be vaporware.
>
> I'd contribute on the kerning, but that would
> require actually
> drawing or modifying glyphs, which I'm disinclined
> to do (I can't
> find a glyph-editing tool that I both like and can
> afford).
>
> (For example, I tried just adding kerning to
> Jerome.ttf, and I found
> that s and t -- the first one I tried -- just won't
> line up, the
> angles of the strokes are too different, and I don't
> have any tools
> to "bulk them up."
>
>
>


__________________________________

You're right, most font editing tools either have not
anough functions or cost a lot. Especialy since I
would only be doing this as a hobby. And yes it would
require both adjusting the kerning and playing with
each chararter's shape. A lot of hand working.

Good luck with your effort!
Chuck
